stem: Click to highlight the findings that require immediate notification to the healthcare provider.
passage: A client experiencing a thyroid storm is being assessed. The nurse notes [restlessness and agitation], [a temperature of 104°F (40°C)], [exophthalmos], [a heart rate of 180 bpm], [BP 90/60], and [diaphoresis]. The client reports [severe abdominal pain] and [vomiting]. Auscultation reveals [coarse crackles] in both lungs. The patient's skin is [flushed and warm to the touch].

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 07:00 S: Patient is a 45-year-old female admitted for hyperthyroidism, now suspected of thyroid storm. Reports increased anxiety and palpitations. B: History of Graves' disease, currently managed with methimazole. A: Restless and agitated. Temperature 104°F (40°C), HR 180 bpm, BP 90/60. Diaphoretic and flushed. Complains of abdominal pain and vomiting. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles bilaterally. R: Provider notified of changes. STAT labs and orders for cooling measures, IV fluids, and beta-blockers requested and pending. Continuous monitoring initiated.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Appears restless, agitated, and diaphoretic. Skin: Flushed and warm to the touch. HEENT: Exophthalmos noted. Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, no murmurs. Respiratory: Coarse crackles auscultated bilaterally. Abdomen: Tender to palpation, patient reports severe pain. Neurological: Anxious, tremulous.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Orders include: Continuous cardiac monitoring, IV fluids (Normal Saline) at 200 mL/hr, Acetaminophen 650 mg PO q4h PRN for fever, Propranolol 1 mg IV q15 min PRN for HR > 140, Cooling blanket, Labs: CBC, CMP, TSH, Free T3 and T4 STAT.

rationale.correct: Thyroid storm is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention. Key findings that warrant immediate notification include: Restlessness and agitation (indicating neurological involvement and escalating crisis), a temperature of 104°F (40°C) (indicating hyperpyrexia, which can cause organ damage), a heart rate of 180 bpm (indicating severe tachycardia, compromising cardiac output), and BP 90/60 (indicating hypotension and potential shock).
rationale.incorrect: Exophthalmos, diaphoresis, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, coarse crackles, and flushed/warm skin are all associated with thyroid storm but are not the highest priority findings requiring immediate notification. They contribute to the overall clinical picture but do not pose the same immediate threat to life as hyperpyrexia, neurological changes, severe tachycardia, or hypotension.

answerBreakdown.label: restlessness and agitation
answerBreakdown.content: Neurological changes like restlessness and agitation indicate the severity of the thyroid storm and its impact on the central nervous system, requiring immediate attention.

answerBreakdown.label: a temperature of 104°F (40°C)
answerBreakdown.content: Hyperpyrexia (temperature >104°F) can lead to organ damage and requires immediate intervention to reduce the body temperature.

answerBreakdown.label: exophthalmos
answerBreakdown.content: Exophthalmos is a characteristic sign of Graves' disease and hyperthyroidism but does not require immediate notification in the context of an acute thyroid storm.

answerBreakdown.label: a heart rate of 180 bpm
answerBreakdown.content: Severe tachycardia compromises cardiac output and can lead to cardiac arrest. Immediate intervention is needed to reduce the heart rate.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 90/60
answerBreakdown.content: Hypotension indicates potential shock and inadequate tissue perfusion, requiring immediate intervention to stabilize blood pressure.

answerBreakdown.label: diaphoresis
answerBreakdown.content: Diaphoresis is a common symptom of thyroid storm but not the highest priority for immediate notification.

answerBreakdown.label: severe abdominal pain
answerBreakdown.content: Abdominal pain can be a symptom of thyroid storm due to increased metabolic demands and stress on the body, but it is not the highest priority for immediate notification compared to vital sign abnormalities and neurological changes.

answerBreakdown.label: vomiting
answerBreakdown.content: Vomiting can occur due to the stress on the body but is not the highest priority for immediate notification.

answerBreakdown.label: coarse crackles
answerBreakdown.content: Coarse crackles indicate fluid in the lungs, possibly due to heart failure related to the thyroid storm, but are not the absolute highest priority compared to immediately life-threatening vital sign changes.

answerBreakdown.label: flushed and warm to the touch
answerBreakdown.content: Flushed and warm skin is a common symptom of thyroid storm due to increased metabolic rate but not the highest priority for immediate notification.

clinicalPearls: Thyroid storm is a medical emergency requiring rapid assessment and treatment to prevent life-threatening complications.
The Burch-Wartofsky Point Scale (BWPS) can be used to assess the likelihood of thyroid storm.
Management includes beta-blockers, thionamides, iodine solutions, and supportive care (cooling, fluids).

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the diagnosis of thyroid storm without prioritizing the most critical and life-threatening signs.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize findings based on their immediate threat to life. Vital sign abnormalities and neurological changes are the highest priorities.
